newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK's Tung to seek views on civil rights dilution.
newsitem.headline: HK's Tung to seek views on civil rights dilution.

text.p: Hong Kong's future leader Tung Chee-hwa will tap public opinion on China's proposal to water down human rights laws after the British colony reverts to China on July 1.
Tung, who has endorsed China's proposals and seen his popularity slip as a result, has commissioned the survey to be carried out next month, a spokeswoman for Tung's office said on Tuesday.
"We will launch a public consultation next month," she said.
China says the civil liberties laws breach the Basic Law, Hong Kong's post-1997 constitution, and that they need to be amended after the July 1 handover.
Tung's popularity has suffered a setback since throwing his weight behind Beijing in repealing the laws, opinion polls show.
A recent survey conducted by Hong Kong's Baptist University found only 53 percent of respondents said they were happy with his performance. British Governor Chris Patten polled 62 percent.
The poll also found 52 percent in Hong Kong opposed Beijing's plan, while only 20 percent supported it.

Tung's standing has suffered further in recent days after concerns about a possible conflict of interest mounted following his decision to appoint a prominent property surveyor as head of a committee to map out long-term housing policy.
Tung, chosen by a China-assembled caucus in December, will succeed from Patten in running Hong Kong after more than 150 years of colonial rule ends at midnight on June 30.
